recordings.rmk: Recorded from close range (~5m) in rather open ca.10-year-old pine/spruce plantation, partially hidden by  tree branches. This two-syllable song type is the only one I've heard at this site.

Chaplin Lake SW side, Saskatchewan
West side of Dog Lake, Saskatchewan
recordings.rmk: Vocalizations from agitated adult perched in willows, presumably near nest site.  "Tink" calls often switched to trilled calls when I took a step, with the trilled calls perhaps signalling increased agitation relative to the tink calls.  Noise of my movement has not been edited out: note the trilled calls often coinciding with my footsteps, switching back to tink calls when I stop moving.  The first instance when this occurs is at 0:52.

Clarkston Rd, Oakland County, Michigan
recordings.rmk:
More than one source of this sounds, meaning more than one bird, if it's bird, on a wide grassy field bordered  with trees.
It sounds as a 3 rasping buzzes of a Clay-colored Sparrow, heard far, so the recording is quite distant.
90% of the times were 3 buzzes and remaining 2 buzzes. Heard for at least 10 minutes.
Although it seems like Clay-colored song, I would like confirmation.

recordings.loc: Gladstone, Delta County, Michigan
recordings.rmk: Loud insect-like sound from bird perched in small (less than 2 meters tall) conifers that had grassy areas between trees. Noisy trucks in background, and noise resulted in needing to trim much of the recording. Recording made as a WAVE file, and converted after cutting to MP3 file. I heard others of its species in the area.  Photo will be put on Flickr. Since both sexes look alike, unable to state the singer was a male. It was cold for May, temperature in 30s F, with a breeze, and becoming overcast.  Other birds in area: pair of Brown Thrashers, pair of Chipping Sparrows, a Vesper Sparrow, Brown-headed Cowbird, and American Robins.

recordings.loc: Algonquin Highlands, Haliburton County, Ontario
recordings.rmk: Trying to identify the double trill heard three times on this recording. This bird was singing across the bay on a steep north facing slope covered with white pine and hemlock. Heard this same bird last year all summer but this is the only place I have heard this song/call. Rest of the area is lakes and mixed hardwood with the odd cabin around the lake shore. This area has Chipping Sparrow and Pine Warbler...so my guess is, it is one of those species. Bird is always far away across bay (100-300 yrds) but sound travels well so I was able to get poor recording.

recordings.loc: Red River National Wildlife Refuge- Headquarters Unit, Bossier Parish, Louisiana
recordings.rmk: Fol xc265061. Poor/noise/vocal competition/ wind.  Playback used briefly at about this time with negative, if any, effect at first- bird seemed to sing less.

recordings.loc: Red River National Wildlife Refuge- Headquarters Unit, Bossier Parish, Louisiana
recordings.rmk: Poor/noise/loudest competition mainly by Carolina Wren, Baltimore Oriole, Red-winged Blackbird. Clay-colored Sparrow is first bird singing, then also later. Recorded while very close to bird giving jumbled, whispered song, occasionally getting louder during portions of song. Habitat somewhat out of character- shady, dense/weedy area edging lake and mowed, orchard-like area near the headquarters building. Singing from small, shrubby tree at around 8'. Photo'd by Charlie Lyon. Spring migrant- quite rare here at this time.

recordings.loc: Algonquin Highlands, Haliburton County, Ontario
recordings.rmk: Singing multiple times from N facing slope covered in Mature Hemlock and White Pine. May be vireo or Purple Finch in background, ovenbird and winterwren.

recordings.loc: Algonquin Highlands, Haliburton County, Ontario
recordings.rmk: 1 double trill from bird singing on North facing mature Hemlock Pine slope around a lake. It was suggested to me that this could be a hybrid because it sounds more trill and less buzzy then most Clay-colored Sparrow...but I have yet to lay eyes on this bird.

recordings.loc: Algonquin Highlands, Haliburton County, Ontario
recordings.rmk: Still trying to identify this creature singing at 1, 7 and 14.5 seconds? Think it is a bird because it seems to move large distances when I try to get close. Singing from Mature White Pine Hemlock slope adjacent to lake. Repeats this double trill once every 3 seconds. Can't get any better quality as it is singing across the water. In addition to listed species, background may also include calling Swainson's Thrush.

recordings.loc: Peterborough, Peterborough County, Ontario
recordings.rmk: This is a record recording because flagged as rare in ebird. Rare breeder in county. Singing from across hayfield adjacent to extensive cattail marsh Miller Creek.

recordings.loc: Lindsay-Parsons Biodiversity Preserve, Danby, NY
recordings.rmk: Recording made with iPhone 5
